#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Protect Food While Camping
#Text=Camping can be a fun and rewarding experience , as long as forest creatures do n't ruin the trip by getting into your supplies .
#Text=Learning how to protect food while camping , keeping it safe from predators big and small , can keep your trip from taking a turn for the worse .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Arrange your campsite properly .
#Text=Store food away from any tents in your campsite .
#Text=Storing food in your tent will attract animals to your sleeping area , and some may go in to predatory mode in trying to access the food you have .
#Text=This is especially critical in camping areas where bears may be present .
#Text=Cook and store food at least away from your camping area .
#Text=Again , food should be prepared and stored in an area that wo n't attract animals to the place you are sleeping .
#Text=Store your food and garbage in your car trunk .
#Text=Only if you have easy access to your car .
#Text=Store food away whenever you are not actively preparing or consuming it .
#Text=This will help keep animals from following the scent of food to your campsite , and provides a barrier they are unable to get through .
#Text=Even coolers should go in the trunk , as animals like raccoons can generally figure out how to break in .
#Text=Keep food in animal-proof containers and positions when a car is not available .
#Text=Some hike-in campsites have food storage boxes available .
#Text=This is generally a small wooden box with a latching or locking lid that is built to keep animals away from your food .
#Text=Make sure the lid is completely secured at all times , and that there are no cracks between the lid and the box .
#Text=Small animals , such as mice and bugs can squeeze through very small openings and ruin your food .
#Text=Also , properly locking the box is important , as animals that live near campgrounds are often very adept at breaking into human contraptions .
#Text=If no food box is available , you 'll need to store your food another way to keep it safe .
#Text=One method is to put it in a canvas or nylon bag and hoist it up onto a tree branch where it can hang in a place that animals ca n't reach it .
#Text=Your food should be hung at least off the ground , out on the branch , and a few feet below the branch .
#Text=You can do this by attaching the rope to a sock filled with rocks , or another heavy object that you can throw , then toss it over a high , sturdy branch .
#Text=Tie the other end to your food bag and hoist it up .
#Text=Your food should be hung at least off the ground , out on the branch , and a few feet below the branch .
#Text=Once the food is hanging at an appropriate height , tie the end in your hands securely to the tree trunk .
#Text=Pack out what you packed in .
#Text=Remember to keep garbage safe the same way you keep food safe .
#Text=Animals will be attracted to your garbage as well as your food , so minimize temptation in order to keep your food safe .
#Text=When you are draining your dishwater , strain it first and toss food particles in with your trash .
#Text=Make sure to dump dishwater at least from your sleeping area and the area where you are keeping your food , because the smell might also attract animals .
#Text=Video
#Text=Tips
#Text=If a racoon does come to your campsite such as when you are around a campfire , do n't scare the racoon off right away ( if you do n't have food out ) .
#Text=Let them explore and see that you do n't have any food .
#Text=The racoon will then realize that you do n't have anything and will stay away .
